commentBody: The other day, I commented about how that day's constructor, Rebecca Goldstein, reliably produces high quality puzzles.  I'll extend the same compliment to Malaika Handa, who has contributed mostly Friday puzzles among her seven so far.
Very fun puzzle, though also a very quick one. Not a  PB, but close.
If I can solve it in 21 minutes, I know it was an easy Friday.
Very nice puzzle, a little chewy at times, but overall quite smooth.

Just saw Elvis Costello in concert last night and was doing some online reading about him today and learned that OLIVIA RODRIGO‚Äôs ‚ÄúBrutal‚Äù owes a big musical debt to Elvis‚Äô ‚ÄúPump it Up.‚Äù When asked why he didn‚Äôt sue her, Elvis said: ‚ÄúI did not find any reason to go after them legally for that, because I think it would be ludicrous,‚Äù Costello continued. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a shared language of music.‚Äù Gotta love the guy! Still in fine form at 70. Here are the two songs: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Y71iDvCYXA (‚ÄúPump it Up‚Äù) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OGUy2UmRxJ0 (‚ÄúBrutal‚Äù) Puzzle was as fizzy as an ORANGE SODA. A really nice Friday puzzle.
Malaika, thank you for a puzzle I needed on a very trying day.
Thoroughly enjoyed also one of my faster Friday solves; 20minutes

"If I had a nickel for every time I thought of a long, fun, debut entry, then put the entry right in the center of my puzzle, and several months later, another themeless puzzle with the exact same entry ran before mine, I‚Äôd have two nickels. Which isn‚Äôt a lot but it‚Äôs weird that it happened twice."

So it happens all the dime, Malaika.


(Enjoyed the puzzle. Smooth with just a bit of crunch.)
Can we get back to Friday puzzles being hard, please?  This might have been a Tuesday just a few years ago.  I'm not asking for one hour puzzles all the time but this was a typing exercise.
That felt more like a Tuesday. Personal best for me. It was a nice puzzle, just the wrong day for it.

After filling in more commonly recognized French and Spanish words across various puzzles, it was nice to see my parents‚Äô native Cantonese represented in POPO (Â©ÜÂ©Ü). I would love to see a crossword in homage to terms of endearment for grandparents around the world. Too niche?

Thanks for the fun, Malaika!

I had to look at the answer key because I had ROTTED crossed with MOOD STONE and legit thought the puzzle might be broken. Guess my Gen X is showing, because being a child of the 1970s, that was glam to me. üòÆü§∑

Unremarkable.  It seemed too fast /easy for a Friday to me.  The clues were fine, if not very exciting/clever.  It's nice that I didn't notice crossword filler.

Funny that I've heard both dozens of times but it never gelled for me that there are famous Menlo Parks in both CA and NJ...

With Spring finally around the corner, nice imagery formed by tan, sundress, donut shop, orange soda and  of course a glass of appletini for TGIF!  I appreciated this puzzle.
This was a nice challenge. The puzzle went much better for me after I gave up on the concept of people caroming from door to door.
I really enjoyed solving this one. The NW was largely blank with the rest of the grid filled in, but fell pretty quickly when their was nowhere else to go and I was forced to focus on it.
Fun puzzle

Next time someone asks if I'd prefer the red or the white, I'll respond, "blue, thanks!" and it's all because of today's puzzle.

Thank you, NYT Crossword, for providing these very high quality jokes that I will use in reality.

That was fun. It was nice to see Olivia Rodrigo featuring in the puzzle a day after the official Glastonbury lineup was released. She's headlining the Pyramid Stage on Sunday night. I'd better start listening to 'Sour' and 'Guts'.
Perfect! Solveable without needing obscure knowledge. Love that! Thanks:)
Fun puzzle!  lol BRA FITTING!
Easy, breezy, Cover Girl. They make PALETTES, right?

Just over 12 minutes.  Less than a dozen fills that I had to go back to more than once.  Nothing wrong with the puzzle, but not at all what I expect on a Friday.  I agree with Andrew.  Can we go back to harder puzzles, especially Thursday-Saturdays?  I  used to spend a good 30-45 minutes on those, sometimes over an hour.  A fabulous way to spend my time.  Now, it's rare to spend more than 20 minutes on one, and that's usually the Sunday grid, only because it's bigger.
Entertaining and fun - I really enjoyed this one.

If the Chinese character sHA means ‚Äúsand‚Äù, I suppose you could have ‚Äúa cupful‚Äù of sand - and the ‚Äús‚Äù in that square would certainly work better for the crosser (in my experience).

Fun puzzle tonight. Thanks, Mailaika Handa!

When I read the clue to 38A [From the beginning] my mind went straight to one of Emerson Lake & Palmer's songs I like the most, named... yup, you got it, "From The Beginning." https://youtu.be/hsJ9YXHqnr8?si=N9vgT4yCKN1GVqN9 (But if you'd like to see cool cat Greg Lake making history for singing live and chewing gum at the same time, here it is: https://youtu.be/yoxHGxQw9ws?si=-R4_ewbV8fJuJ6S6) I enjoyed the puzzle and loved [Crush.] That one made me laugh out loud (for real.) Does it even still exist? I assume it must, but I haven't looked for it nor have I had it in decades. I can't even remember now which one I liked better - Crush or Fanta. I'll admit to looking up the IRON THRONE answer so as to break open the SE quadrant. I may very well be the only person in the nation who hasn't watched GoT. All in all, a great start to the weekend. Thank you Ms. Handa!

I guess I'm feeling a bit bleak or geared up for a fight at the moment, because all I could think for 11D was LASTSTAnd... Hmm.

Well, I didn't know OLIVIARODRIGO off hand (though I've heard her name, so got it with a handful of crosses), so I kept trying to work the ND in, but ANEW would have nothing of it, so I relented.

Can not believe how fast I sailed through this one, filling in long answers on the first round and all. I only slowed a bit in the SE. I knew BENIN and GHEE but struggled to remember the cheap beer even though I knew I knew it. APPLETINIS helped me out a lot though. 

Anyhow, it was breezy feeling for me but I enjoyed it. Not the struggle that Fridays can be for me, which is good because all day today I thought it was Friday, which is going to make tomorrow a bit rough. 

So, well, Sam sorta brought it up by mentioning calculators... and BRAFITTING is in the puzzle, so just gonna ask, who remembers what 55378008 on a calculator spells out upside down?  üòÇ

Ohhhh, to be 13 again! (No thanks!) 

Off to shake up a legit marTINI now! Another perk of not being 13! (Although, I grew up in rural WI, you know there were a few PBRs involved in my misspent youth.)

Game of Thrones! Ghee, I forgot all about that! It's the perfect series for right now. Fantasy for March 7th: for me, movie magic would be watching a beautiful queen rigged out in a sun dress of moonstones (no "fitting" required) soaring high astride Smoke, her dragon, laying fiery waste to the stadt the clownish orange-soda-colored king (did he spend his life in a donut shop?) on his iron throne thought was his, making his pet apes literally eat dirt, while the true prince from Kiev prevails in his final stage showdowns with the rotten chief of the former Bloc countries, and can rid his country of the constant raid of nits. While in Menlo Park a strange inertia takes hold of the tech bros, and bit by bit, nano by nano, the whole internet disappears, like a moon on the wane, and with the dawn, the people wake, the world has begun anew, and one will say to another, "Oh, I see now. I was no wiser before, but now I have the key. Home is the most beautiful word." And I go on a blind date with Olivia Rodrigo to a basketball game where Angel Reese scores a jillion points, and then go to a mod hipster wine bar that also serves kale chips, PBRs and appletinis, and Rahm Emanuel, thank God, is nowhere to be found. Wouldn't that be movie magic?

I post this sort of general comment once in a while when I expect a deluge of "too easy" complaints.  Looks like it's coming tonight.  I swear I'm starting to get a stomach ache when a puzzle is coming fairly quickly because I know we're in for "these puzzles aren't like the old days...".

If you, for the very first time solved a Friday puzzle cleanly according to your personal definition of "clean", then congratulate yourself and be happy.

Don't let all those who sniff at "too easy" Friday puzzles ruin it for you.

A Friday is a Friday.  Some are harder than others.

I prefer chicken Kyiv.
It's a Ukrainian dish.

"Too easy for a Friday," they say. "It belongs on the back of the box of General Mills' latest sugar-kibble!"
I did solve it faster than normal, (but maybe I'm just getting better at solving them). I guess I just dont like it when someone poops on the puzzle I feel good about solving. Oh well, Im still happy with myself!

I very much enjoyed this one. I was definitely on the same wavelength because the long answers came easily - like BRAFITTING! And ALONETIME - one of my favorite things! A very pleasant puzzle experience.

This ended up being too hard for me to solve on my own. 

On my first across and down pass I had very little, but I was determined to complete the puzzle without lookups, so I persevered(-ish) and managed to fill most of the grid in 20 minutes.

I was left (I thought) with the NE corner. I had "pact" for "alliance", I did not know the Chicago politician (just as none of you know any politicians from Gda≈Ñsk, Rzesz√≥w or Wroc≈Çaw), for some reasons wANS made sense to me for "darkens in the light"... There was no way out of this mess for me, I thought. But then I realized pact would in fact be BLOC. I was still quite confused though so I broke down and looked up RAHM. Then I kept staring at BRAFITwING and I just could not parse it... So I went to the column for help. BRA FITTING... D'oh! I know that's a thing! But it did not come to me...

Well, ok, anyway - I put in the correct letter there and... I got the dreaded "So close" popup. By then I was just tired by the whole thing so I checked the puzzle.

Turned out the drink from China is not teA (it is though, isn't it?), but CHA... Yes, I know the other words there did not make sense with the t and a from teA, but I was so certain of teA I never checked my crosses there, especially as I had no idea who Laura Ingalls was.

Btw, do the languages we need to know to solve NYT puzzles now include Cantonese, too (POPO)? Spanish, French, some German and now a dialect of Chinese? Ok...

I guess I did not like this one much.
I had ROTTED crossing MOODSTONE.  Did I discover a legitimate alternate solution?
That didn‚Äôt feel like a Friday at all. Very easy. More like a Wednesday. It took me only 10 mins and that was because I had a typo and had to hunt it down.

When money is borrowed, it needs its a-loan time.

(This pun is current, see?)
From nerdy entries like INERTIA and RAID, to smart puns like BRAFITTING and TANS, and even relatable quips like how we all need some ALONETIME, this puzzle was a homerun for me. Totally enjoyed it!
Just smashed my personal Friday record by more than half‚Ä¶

I like the long, stacked, crossing entries with a symmetry that's pleasing to the eye. I found myself wondering which words seeded this puzzle. Surely IRON THRONE or OLIVEA RODRIGO didn't just come about by chance during the construction of this grid. BRA FITTING though... too funny.

Argh! I was truly stuck with the apt 25A [Still confused]. I had NOW I SEe instead of NO WISER. Never mind that SEE crosses itself and that I will never, ever remember RSS. Even so, it was a fun puzzle.
Friday record for me. DONUTSHOP clue made me giggle. Nice puzzle !

Fun puzzle!  I appreciate the notable absence of sports trivia, except for one WNBA mention.  I‚Äôm working through the NYT archives as distraction from current events, and clues like ‚Äú1956 NHL MVP‚Äù or ‚ÄúLIV Super Bowl winners‚Äù kind of drive me bonkers.

Reading these comments can really bruise the ego.

Had to slowly piece together OLIVIA RODRIGO, which makes sense for someone who still loves The Strawberry Alarm Clock.
ROTTEN/n crossed with MOON/dSTONE felt like a Natick to me except I knew both words. Is there a sword term for that?

Quite tricky for me, but once I accepted I had to reveal OLIVIA -  and the - THRONE it went quite well. My lack of knowledge of popular culture is boundless. 
Not familiar with PHONO, I used a record player, or HORAS.

AHA I thought, the ruler wouldn't be centimetres .... and tried hard to think of something non-metric.
Some clever cluing here but that same recurrent experience of having dwelled in the bland referential world of the gen-x mind.

Fun puzzle, no complaints here. 

I‚Äôm either having a ripper week or the crosswords have been relatively easy this week. Set a PB on both Monday and Tuesday and now a PB for Friday. Wednesday tripped me up a bit but the Thursday theme was also such a joy. 

Solid week NYT. Looking forward to tomorrow.

An admin for an online forum is the "admin".

A mod(erator) is generally considered a different concept.
Not a personal best for a Friday but well below my average time. Makes me worry that tomorrow will be a reversion to the mean day. üò¨üòâ

Generally an enjoyable puzzle with a handful of regulars thrown in, (MENLO, ANEW, AWE, ANON, NGOS), this puzzle did have some well written clues that were ambiguous enough to confuse.

I found no traction at the start and began making headway after jumping at BLINDDATES, eventually filling in the SW corner enough to get OLIVIARODRIGO and ALONETIME. ORANGESODA gave me a toehold into the SW corner while RAHM eventually got me through the NE section.

After RAFTS, NOWISER and PALETTES I thought I was home free, even though FETTID was misspelled I was certain ROTTED was not.

TEA before CHA and ROTTED before ROTTEN.

Cheers

Easy, breezy beautiful palette of words! For those that felt they‚Äôd like the fun to last a wee bit longer, I‚Äôll give you a shiny red penny if this doesn‚Äôt make you audibly chuckle. Bargatze on a show you may have heard about. It‚Äôs called SNL. Short for‚Ä¶something. https://youtu.be/JYqfVE-fykk?si=NrjXliKWTMiq-FWr Happy Friday all!

AS A rule, I don't go on many BLIND DATES, but I a friend set me up on one which proved quite memorable--I opened the door, and there stood Michael Stipe, of REM! I plied him with APPLETINIS, red and white WINES, black-and-TANS, cans of PBR, even DONUT SHOP coffee, but all he wanted was a cup of fresh brewed CHA. For dinner, I prepared a KALE OMELET, and a classic dish of chicken supremes, neatly trimmed into ovals and stuffed with herbed GHEE. He would have none of it, and prepared to leave, making excuses that he needed some "ALONE TIME." Was it because I used that pre-washed baby kale AS IS, wehich turned out to be half ROTTEN and full of GRIT*, so it tasted like one ATE DIRT? Or because, insensitively, I had not called it Chicken KyiV? I was NO WISER, until one of my BFFs--was it Emmanuel or Olivia? I don't remember.--informed me it was simply because Stipe is Vegetarian! OH, I SEE NOW! All this as a set-up to offer, from *Green*--https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_mSmOcmk7uQ *which, ironically, happens to be the name of an erstwhile vegetarian restaurant in Athens, GA, located in a building which Stipe owned--look it up!

A zing-fest:
‚Ä¢	That vertical three-stack in the NE ‚Äì BRA FITTING, LAST STAGE, and OH I SEE NOW.  All are NYT answer debuts.  Debuts aren‚Äôt automatically good, but these are.
‚Ä¢	Malaika‚Äôs puzzles always feel contemporary, and there‚Äôs brio in that.
‚Ä¢	This NYT debut grid design allows for a colossal 15 longs, many of which shimmered.

A pair of lovely serendipities: 
‚Ä¢	The contradictory cross of OH I SEE NOW and NO WISER. 
‚Ä¢	A backward NONA to go with NANO. 

And a heart-warming reminder of World Central Kitchen (in the clue for NGOS).  This group set up here in Asheville immediately after Helene and was all over the place feeding those in need, with local chefs jumping right in.  Then there they were in California right after the fires.  They are wonder-workers.

All this brightness in the box, for which I‚Äôm immensely grateful.  Thank you, Malaika!

The ASA rule I recall is:
Take two aspirins and call me in the morning.

This was a good, solid Friday for me,
but no headaches.
(only got O.Rodrigo thanks to the showdowns)

2nd post-- By weird coincidence, last night my Partner and I attended a concert by the DSO, including Mussorgsky's *Pictures at an Exhibition*, in the orchestration by Maurice Ravel (whose 150th birthday is today!): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TU-w2eIyVyA (This performance by the CSO under Muti.)

A byte frequently, but by no means always, consists of eight bits.

Close enough for a crossword clue,  though.

A fairly fluid solve for me. After an initial smattering of fly specks, my eyes landed on ORANGE SODA, something I loved as a kid, and I had a taste of the sweet success to come.

I wish I could share Sam‚Äôs enthusiasm for themeless puzzles. Often they don‚Äôt thrill me. It‚Äôs not that I can‚Äôt solve them, but sometimes they just feel like a chore that needs to be done. To the contrary, hats off to Malaika for making a Friday themeless fun! I thoroughly enjoyed this one. Thanks!
Kind of hoped for a pic of Roddy McDowall today.  That was some old time special effects.
Who loves ORANGE SODA?
I agree Sam.  Friday is my favorite puzzle day and the one I am most excited for each week and the saddest when I am done because I have to wait another week.  This was a smooth solve today.
In this Friday SHOWDOWN, I took the IRON THRONE from M. Handa. A celebration calls for WINE or I may get crazy and have an ORANGE SODA, a favorite for DALE.

Love seeing Heinz in the constructor notes!

This was a great, fast puzzle. Not loving 5D, but it comes out from crosses. The one that got me is that I confidently filled in KIT for 41A and couldn't believe it was wrong, which kept the obvious answer for 41D out of reach. Still, all resolved quite quickly and it was a very fun solve!

Is there a way to reset the timer to zero if one, say, opens the puzzle but then falls asleep and awakes many hours later to find a still-blank grid and 11 minutes on the clock? Asking for a friend‚Ä¶

This one started slowly (in more ways than one), and seemed nearly impenetrable at first. But once things started to click, they clicked rapidly and I somehow ended up about 10 minutes under my average time. I found the clueing to be challenging yet intuitive. Nice puzzle!
Any puzzle that makes me think of J.D. and his love for APPLETINIS is a good puzzle in my book. Thanks Malaika!
I'm familiar with jumping beans, but DO NUTS HOP?

This puzzle took me quite some time,  and it has left me with serious questions:

Who slices their hard-boiled eggs the long way?
If I lost my mind and decided to use eye shadow, would I have to buy a PALETTE?  Srsly?
Didn't MOOD rings go out of style in the 70's?
If you serve someone KALE for dinner, what is the message?
      (I can tell you what DHubby would think...)

I haven't really found it useful to add MEd or  BSEd  to my name.  People think anyone can teach and that there's nothing really to know about pedagogy...which might explain why our students lag behind those of most other advanced... oh, never mind.

My daughter's kids are not allowed to have soda; there is none at home. But they, of course, hear about it at school. It is a well-known fact, however, that "Grandma never says no." Let the record show that my daughter is the one who told them that; I never did. I follow their rules to the letter, and only bend them when specifically told that it's okay.

So when I had the kids for a couple of days a couple of summers ago, we were at a restaurant (only outdoors ones where permitted), and grandson asked if he could order an orange soda. I knew he wasn't going to drink it, so I let him order it, with a glass of water. He drank three sips of the huge soda (definitely a whole can of Crush in that glass) and then abandoned it. 

Mom and Dad approved, and he still, now and then, will order a soda, and not drink it. Granddaughter (two years older) shakes her head at him, in an older sister way, and orders water. "It's bad for your teeth!" she reminds him. 

I did love this puzzle; and my favorite clue was "Service for someone who needs support?" for BRAFITTING. And that's another story. But, maybe we'll skip that one today...
Perhaps appropriate,with BRAFITTING everything fell into place.

Like most Fridays, out of a blank grid, and few squares fill, and then it begins to gel. Great feeling! 
I was an orange soda girl. NOT orange drink -it had to be fizzy. 
Nedicks, anyone?

Aha! The photo is probably inspired by OLIVIA, since the celebration is BOLIVIAN. That‚Äôs my guess, anyway.

I wonder whether there was meant to be a double bluff with the obvious LPS, CMS, etc. I held off on those, thinking they were too obvious, only to see them fill in. STADT for German city definitely is in that category.

I filled in RSS quickly, but only because I remember never understanding it.

Far too much "trivia" for my liking, but seemingly a fair puzzle, given that I solved it unaided while not knowing much of the trivia. 

Seemed very gentle for a Friday puzzle.

Absolutely flew through this one at near record pace, but got stuck on the CHA/CHIT cross and had to run through the alphabet. Well, it‚Äôs a good day to learn a new word! I‚Äôve never heard ‚Äúchit‚Äù in all my almost 5 decades.

That was fun. Filled in OLIVIA and got enough of the others to guess that RODRIGO might be her last name. 

I'm old.

A while back, Queen Elizabeth (second of her name, and mother of corgis) had occasion to tour the set of Game of Thrones, in Northern Ireland. An internet meme followed quickly, showing her gazing at the IRON THRONE, with the caption, "Windsor is Coming."
Haven't seen a reference to WASP(Y) in years and years. Made me laugh though. Thank you.
I'm a guy who doesn't always get the Wednesday puzzle and rarely gets the Thursday puzzle. Can someone explain why I have a three-week Friday streak?

Fun solve today! I think it aligned well with brain space so it went pretty smoothly. Those always feel nice. Although it took me longer than I care to say to parse NOWISER. Something about it just look so weird to me. Finally got there. Aha! Still looks weird though, haha.
With OH NOW I SEE right there, I thought 25A was meant to be parsed as ‚Äúnow I se- er‚Ä¶‚Äù , which was quite a stretch! Relieved to see that the answer (and myself) was NO WISER.

Kale? For dinner? This is why people voted for Trump!
Fine crossword, it works as Sam says in the piece. I doubt I'll remember it after today for any particular reason, but that's not a problem. Many others I remember only negatively, but I was content with the entries and cluing today - many thanks Malaika!
Just wanted to thank the constructor for a perfectly pleasant puzzle. What a nice start to my Friday.

This was a fun one, and a little kinder than many Fridays. It wasn‚Äôt easy, as least for me, but it was fairly accessible. I looked up OLIVIA RODRIGO, which is way out of my wheelhouse. But the misdirects in this puzzle were great, and I got many of them, which made me happy. My favorite was ‚Äúred or white, but not blue‚Äù. So clever and I didn‚Äôt get it on my first pass through the puzzle, but when it did come to me I was quite pleased. 
Thanks so much, Malaika Handa. Please keep up the good work. I need my daily puzzles now more than ever.
A little on the easy side for a Friday but still required some effort. That was a fun one!

I've heard the names of many of the modern-day celebs, but I have no idea what they do.  Olivia Rodrigo is one of these.  Don't know if she's a singer, dancer, or math professor at Cal Tech.  Once I filled in some down clues I managed to suss out the rest.

39 across is a controversial take! Especially considering the not-too-long ago exploration of the theme in this very paper : What Is a Sundress? https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2024/07/03/style/sundress-quiz-summer-dress.html?smid=nytcore-android-share An enjoyable Friday, in spite of this

good crossword. i enjoyed doing it. :)

But that gave me EAST STAGE for "Final phase," and I was thinking maybe that was some reference to a movie I'd never seen. Thank goodness for BRA FITTING, which finally set me straight!

Really enjoyed the puzzle today! I was proud of myself to get KALE right away lol

My favorite crossword moments are when I can't figure a word out and finally get it on crossings, and still don't recognize it as a word for a moment.

BRAFITTING got me today.

I just want to clarify 4D; while traditionally WINE is made using red and white grapes to produce a something that is white, red, pink, or orange; an unfortunate (but short lived) trend started in 2016 when the Spanish company G√Øk began making blue wine. They use different dyes and pigments to achieve the blue color, with novelty being the selling point. Additives can also be used in more traditional winemaking, such as Mega Purple to deepen the color, and there are over 60 additives legally allowed in U.S. wines!

I tried to make note of my favorite clues as solved but there were too many lol. 

Also I made the same TEAM error as many and had to rework the NE to finish. Actually laughed out loud when I realized the support service was BRAFITTING (which should have been a gimmie lol) and had no issue finishing from there. 

Another Malaika favorite!
I think for once, being a gen-z helped me today in getting Olivia Rodrigo right away. I normally struggle with a lot of the older references in these puzzles!
Love the lighthearted clues! Made me think of happy things!
Very late Gen X male who got OLIVIARODRIGO and BRAFITTING immediately. I don‚Äôt know what that says about me.

Every time a Friday or Saturday puzzle is "too easy", we reargue if the puzzles used to be harder.

A lot of long term solvers say they are, and I guess I have to believe them.  They do make an argument, and can counter my suggestions that it might be otherwise.

So, they're getting easier.

But you have to admit that puts the newer solver (last couple of years) in a conundrum:

"I got a Monday with no cheats!"
"But wait till you get to Fridays and Saturdays. They're harder."
"I got a Friday/Saturday with no cheats!"
"Yeah, but they're easier than they used to be."

I came to the comments to see if everyone else found this significantly easier than usual for a Friday.  Seems to be the case.  I did the puzzle standing in a noisy gymnasium, holding a water bottle in one hand and doing the crossword with the hand I'm holding the phone with.  Not exactly a recipe for speed, but I got a PB by a lot.  I think I was 10 minutes faster than my current average speed for Friday.  12 minutes today.  That's not super fast for a lot of you, but that is like a normal Wednesday for me.
mental bloc... in NE
Get ready.  Saturday's coming at us.

First, with the written language, it's a pictograph system. There is traditional and simplified.

Just out of curiosity, I took a look at the puzzle that was run almost exactly 10 years ago, on Friday, March 6, 2015, and found that my time was almost three times as long as today's time.

On the other hand, I looked at the clues and answers, and thought that, other than a few things that would have been more obvious 10 years ago, like a website that was more prominent then, it didn't seem like it would have taken me all that time today.

I think that whether or not the puzzles have become easier, the complainers often do not take into account that (a) they are better solvers than they were many years ago, and (b) if you try to solve an older puzzle, you'll be hindered by out-of-date references that might have been more obvious back then.

@Steve L 

On the other hand‚Ä¶the xwstats median for March 6 2015 is 37:14, as opposed to 12:03 today.

I suppose it‚Äôs possible that the cohort of solvers whose times are reflected in xwstats has been relatively static over the last 10 years, during which time the group‚Äôs solving skills has been steadily increasing‚Ä¶but come on, let‚Äôs be real, average puzzle difficulty has gone waaay down during the last few years, particularly on Fridays and Saturdays.

I don‚Äôt universally hate this trend ‚Äî in part because some of the old Saturdays were just plain diabolical (and contained a level of esoterica in trivia and vocabulary that would break the comments section nowadays), and in part because I‚Äôve got a couple decades‚Äô worth of unsolved puzzles in the archive.
